turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: Do you want to hear it or not?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Yes. But you might try and spice it up with a little originality.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: I got up. I ate breakfast and went shopping. During the afternoon I read a novel.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: Then I fixed supper for my husband and waited until --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Your husband! Mrs. Robinson! There's something we could have a conversation about.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I mean everything. I don't know anything about how you -- how you work this. I don't know how you get out of the house at night. I don't know the risk involved.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: How do you get out of the house?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You walk right out the door.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: What do you say to him?

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: Benjamin, this isn't a very interesting topic.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Please. Now tell me. How do you know he won't wake up sometime and follow you.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: Because he takes sleeping pills. He takes three sleeping pills every night at ten o'clock.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: But what about the noise from the car. What if --

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: The driveway's on my side of the house.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: We're talking, Mrs. Robinson. We're talking.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: Can I undress and talk at the same time?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Now. You say the driveway's on your side of the house. So I guess you don't sleep in the same room.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: So you don't -- I mean I don't like to seem like I'm prying but I guess you don't sleep together or anything.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well how long has this been going on.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Oh no. Are you kidding me?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You have not slept with your husband for five years?

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: Now and then. He gets drunk a few times a year.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: On New Year's Eve. Sometimes on his birthday.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: So you don't love him. You wouldn't say you --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Wait a minute. So you wouldn't say you loved him.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: No, Benjamin. I don't hate him. Unhook my blouse.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well how do you feel about him, then?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well that's kind of a bad situation then, isn't it?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I mean it doesn't sound like it could be much worse. If you hated him at least you'd hate him.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well you loved him once, I assume. When you first knew him.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: I never did, Benjamin. Now let's --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well, wait a minute. You married him.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I can't see why you did, unless... you didn't have to marry him or anything, did you?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Oh no. You had to marry him because you got pregnant?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well I never thought of you and Mr. Robinson as the kind of people who...

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: All right. Now let's get to bed.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Wait a minute. Wait a minute. So how did it happen?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I mean do you feel like telling me what were the circumstances?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Was he a law student at the time?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: And you were a student also.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: Why are you asking me all this?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Because I'm interested, Mrs. Robinson. Now what was your major subject at college?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: But I thought you -- I guess you kind of lost interest in it over the years then.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I mean did he take you up to his room with him? Did you go to a hotel?

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: Benjamin, what does it possibly matter?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Oh no. In the car you did it?

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: I don't think we were the first.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: What kind of car was it?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Do you remember the make of the car?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: A Ford! A Ford! Goddamnit, a Ford! That's great!

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: So old Elaine Robinson got started in a Ford.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: Because I don't want you to.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well why is she a big taboo subject all of a sudden?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well -- I guess I'll have to ask her out on a date and find out what's --

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: Benjamin, don't you ever take that girl out.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well look. I have no intention of taking her out.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Let's hear your reasons, Mrs. Robinson. Because I think I know what they are.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I'm not good enough for her to associate with, am I? I'm not good enough to even talk about her, am I?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: We're not dropping it. Now that's the reason, isn't it? I'm a dirty degenerate, aren't I? I'm not fit to --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I'm good enough for you but I'm too slimy to associate with your daughter. That's it, isn't it? ISN'T IT?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You go to hell. You go straight to hell, Mrs. Robinson. Do you think I'm proud of myself? Do you think I'm proud of this?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: No sir. I am not proud that I spend my time with a broken-down alcoholic!

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: And if you think I come here for any reason besides pure boredom, then you're all wrong.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Because -- Mrs. Robinson this is the sickest, most perverted thing that ever happened to me. And you do what you want but I'm getting the hell out.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: That I'm a sick and disgusting person.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: Don't you expect me to be a little hurt?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Mrs. Robinson, you stand there and tell me I'm not good enough for your daughter.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: Benjamin, I want to apologize to you if that's the impression you got.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well two minutes ago you told me I wasn't good enough for your daughter. Now you say you're sorry I got that impression.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: I didn't mean it. I don't think you'd be right for each other. But I would never say you weren't as good a person as she is.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: Well it's pretty obvious you don't want me around any more.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well look -- I was kind of upset there.  I'm sorry I said those things.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: That's all right. I think I can understand why I'm disgusting to you.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Oh no.  Look -- I like you. I wouldn't keep coming here if I didn't like you.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: But if it's sickening for you --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: It's not! I enjoy it! I look forward to it. It's the one thing I have to look forward to.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: You don't have to say that.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well I wouldn't. I would never say it if it wasn't true.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Yes. Please. I want you to.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well don't thank me, because I want you to.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Look. Why the hell did you bring this up. It never occurred to me to take her out.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: Then give me your word you won't.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: All right, for christ's sake. I promise I will never take out Elaine Robinson.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Let's not talk about it. Let's not talk at all.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Now listen -- this was not my idea. It was my father's idea.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: Benjamin -- I thought I made myself perfectly clear about this.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Look, we'll go out to dinner and have a drink and I'll bring her back. Because it was either that or a dinner party for the two families. And I'm afraid I couldn't quite handle that, if you don't mind. I have no intention of ever taking your precious daughter out again in her life. So don't get upset about it.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: But I am. I'm extremely upset about it, Benjamin.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Mrs. Robinson -- I have a date with Elaine. We're going for a drive.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: Listen to me very carefully, Benjamin. You are not to see Elaine again. Ever. Those are my orders. Is that clear?

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: I can makes things quite unpleasant.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: In order to keep Elaine away from you -- I am prepared to tell her everything.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: Then you'd better start believing me.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Mrs. Robinson, don't wreck it. I'm asking you please not to wreck it.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I just don't believe you would do that.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: Hello. Get me the police, please.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: I'll be with you in a moment, Benjamin.  Will you send a police car to twelve hundred Glenview Road. We have a burgler here. Just a second. I'll ask him.  Are you armed?  No -- I don't believe he is. Thank you.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: What have you done to her?

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: I think we have everything quite under control now, Benjamin. Would you like a quick drink before you go?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: You can't stop me from seeing her, Mrs. Robinson. I'll find her.

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: I'm sorry we won't be able to invite you to the wedding, Benjamin, but the arrangements have been so rushed --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: What the hell have you done?

turns.speaker: MRS. ROBINSON
turns.text: Ahh. I don't think you'll have time for that drink after all.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: The toothbrush. I got it all right.

turns.speaker: MRS. SINGLEMAN
turns.text: I'd like you to know my sister, Miss DeWitte --

turns.speaker: MRS. SINGLEMAN
turns.text: I'll find your table in a moment. Braddock. Not Braniff? We have a Braniff.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: No -- actually I'm just looking for a friend.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I'm not with your party -- I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: MRS. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Say hello to Mrs. Robinson, Benjamin.

turns.speaker: MRS. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Can I talk to you a minute?

turns.speaker: MRS. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Benjamin? I'm going to ask you something but you don't have to tell me if you don't want.

turns.speaker: MRS. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Well I'm going to ask you what you do when you go off at night.

turns.speaker: MRS. BRADDOCK
turns.text: You don't have to tell me if you don't want.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: No, I do. I want to tell you.

turns.speaker: MRS. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Well you don't drive around from midnight until noon the next day, Benjamin.

turns.speaker: MRS. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Then what do you do? Do you meet someone?

turns.speaker: MRS. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Well this is your business, Benjamin.  If you --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I don't meet anyone, mother, but why did you say that?

turns.speaker: MRS. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Benjamin, I'm not going to pry into your affairs, but I'd rather you didn't say anything at all than be dishonest. Goodnight, Benjamin.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well why do you -- why do you think that?

turns.speaker: MRS. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Because I know you don't drive around for twelve hours.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Oh. Well, I don't. Shall I tell you what I do?

turns.speaker: MRS. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Not if you don't want to.

turns.speaker: MRS. BRADDOCK
turns.text: But I don't want you to make up something.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I'm not. But I'm -- I'm not very proud of what I do. I usually get kind of drunk. I usually drive over to Los Angeles and go to some bars and get kind of drunk. Then I take a hotel room. So I won't have to drive home on the freeway. I mean it kind of scares me to drive home after --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: But I want you to. Please. Please will you believe me.

turns.speaker: MRS. BRADDOCK
turns.text: It's pretty embarrassing. I really don't know what to tell Mr. Robinson. It's awkward and strained for me every time he suggests that you call up Elaine.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Next time he suggests it, I'll tell him I have no intention of ever calling her up in my life.

turns.speaker: MRS. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Don't go on like this. Now if Benjamin absolutely refuses to take her out --

turns.speaker: MRS. BRADDOCK
turns.text: -- then I'll simply invite all the Robinsons' over for dinner on Thursday.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I'm going up to Berkeley today.

turns.speaker: MRS. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Oh, Ben -- this is so -- exciting --

turns.speaker: MRS. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Well -- when did you decide all this?

turns.speaker: MRS. BRADDOCK
turns.text: When did you two talk this over?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I don't know. I want it to be --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Well -- it's very comfortable -- just to drift here.

turns.speaker: MR. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Have you thought about graduate school?

turns.speaker: MR. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Would you mind telling me then -- what were those four years of college for? What was the point of all that hard work?

turns.speaker: MR. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Now listen, Ben. I think it's a very good thing that a young man -- after he's done some very good work -- should have a chance to relax and enjoy himself, and lie around, and drink beer and so on. But after a few weeks I believe that person would want to take some stock in himself and his situation and start to think about getting off his ass.

turns.speaker: MR. BRADDOCK
turns.text: I guess she's not good enough for you, is that it?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Look -- Elaine Robinson and I do not get along.

turns.speaker: MR. BRADDOCK
turns.text: How do you know? You haven't seen her since high school. I guess your evenings, whatever you do with them, are just too valuable.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: That has nothing to do with it --

turns.speaker: MR. BRADDOCK
turns.text: I guess I'll just tell Mr. Robinson that you're just too busy every evening -- doing God knows what --

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I'm going to marry Elaine Robinson.

turns.speaker: MR. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Come on, let's call the Robinsons. We've got something to celebrate.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: No. I think you'll want to wait on that.

turns.speaker: MR. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Wait a minute. You talked to Elaine this morning?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: No. She doesn't know about it.

turns.speaker: MR. BRADDOCK
turns.text: She doesn't know that you're coming up to Berkeley?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: No. Actually -- she doesn't know about us getting married yet.

turns.speaker: MR. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Ben -- this whole idea sounds pretty half-baked.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: No -- it's not. It's completely baked. It's a decision I've made.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I drove -- I drove Mrs. Robinson home. She wanted me to drive her home so I -- I drove her home.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: She's upstairs. She wanted me to wait down here till you got home.

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: Standing guard over the old castle, are you?

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: Here. It looks like you need a refill.

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: Is anything wrong? You look a little shaken up.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: No. No -- I'm just -- I'm just a little worried about my future. I'm a little upset about my future.

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: Ben -- how old are you now?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Twenty. I'll be twenty-one next week.

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: That's a hell of a good age to be.

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: I wish I was that age again. Because, Ben --

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: Ben, can I say something to you?

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: How long have we known each other now?

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: How long have you and I known each other? How long have your Dad and I been partners?

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: I've watched you grow up, Ben.

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: In many ways I feel as though you were my own son.

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: So I hope you won't mind my giving you a friendly piece of advice.

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: Ben -- I think -- I think you ought to be taking it a little easier right now than you seem to.

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: You have yourself a few flings this summer. I bet you're quite a ladies' man.

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: What? You look like the kind of guy that has to fight them off.  Doesn't he look to you like the kind of guy who has to fight them off?

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: Oh say -- Elaine gets down from Berkeley on Saturday.

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: Ben -- I want you to give her a call.

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: Hi, Ben. What are you doing with yourself these days?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Oh -- not too much. Taking it easy.

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: That's what I'd do if I could. Nothing wrong with that. Hey Ben, Elaine's coming down from Berkeley soon. I want you to call her up this time.

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: Because I just think you two would hit it off real well together.

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: What would you say to a short one? Bourbon still your drink?

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: Do you want -- do you want to try and tell me why you did it?

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: Do you have a special grudge against me? Do you feel a particularly strong resentment for me?

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: Is there something I've said that's caused this contempt? Or is it just the things I stand for that you despise?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: It was nothing to do with you, sir.

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: Well, Ben, it was quite a bit to do with me.

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: Ben, I think we're two civilized human beings. Do you think it's necessary to threaten each other?

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: Do you want to unclench your fists, please? Thank you. I can see in the dark, you know. I've been here quite a while.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: I am trying to tell you I have no personal feelings about you, Mr. Robinson. I am trying to tell you I do not resent you.

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: You don't respect me terribly much either, do you?

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: Well, I don't think we have a whole lot to say to each other, Ben. I do think you should know the consequences of what you've done. I do think you should know that my wife and I are getting a divorce soon.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: It shouldn't make any difference what happened.

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: Listen to me. We got -- we got into bed with each other. But it was nothing. It was nothing at all. We might -- we might just as well have been shaking hands.

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: Shaking hands. Well, that's not saying much for my wife, is it?

turns.speaker: BEN
turns.text: The point is -- I don't love your wife. I love your daughter, sir.

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: Well -- I'm sure you think you do, Ben, but after a few times in bed with Elaine I feel quite sure you'd get over that as quickly as you --

turns.speaker: MR. ROBINSON
turns.text: I think I've talked about this enough. I don't know how far I can go, Ben. I don't know if I can prosecute or not, but I think maybe I can. In the light of what's happened I think maybe I can get you behind bars if you ever look at my daughter again. I have seen Elaine and I have spent the afternoon taking steps to insure...

turns.speaker: BEN'S VOICE
turns.text: Can you look through the glass.

turns.speaker: MR. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Are you ready in there, feature attraction?

turns.speaker: BEN'S VOICE
turns.text: Could I speak to you for a second, Dad?

turns.speaker: BEN'S VOICE
turns.text: Dad -- could we just talk about this for a second?

turns.speaker: MR. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Twenty-one-years-old, ladies and gentlemen; four of those years spent accomplishing some rather extraordinary things at one of our nation's leading seats of learning --

turns.speaker: MR. BRADDOCK
turns.text: I can't hold them much longer, Ben. You better get out here.

turns.speaker: MR. BRADDOCK
turns.text: This boy -- I'm sorry -- this young man -- is soon to continue his education as a Frank Halpingham Award Scholar -- but before he does --

turns.speaker: MR. BRADDOCK
turns.text: -- before he does --  You're disappointing them, Ben. You're disappointing them.

turns.speaker: MR. BRADDOCK
turns.text: I'll give you ten seconds.  He is going to give us a practical demonstration of what I feel safe in saying is a pretty exciting birthday present -- and it better work or I'm out over two hundred bucks -- so let's hear it for --

turns.speaker: MR. BRADDOCK
turns.text: No! No -- we're just on our way downstairs!

turns.speaker: MRS. BRADDOCK
turns.text: They came all the way from Tarzana.

turns.speaker: MR. BRADDOCK
turns.text: It's a wonderful thing to have so many devoted friends.

turns.speaker: MR. BRADDOCK
turns.text: Ben says he and Elaine are getting married.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Oh yes -- that's right -- look! I win, don't I --

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: I'm having luck for the first time in my life.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: I oughtn't to presume, but I --  I'm so grateful to you -- it's been so marvelous. The first time in my life I have gambled -- I've danced! Oh, you can laugh, gentlemen, but it's the first time in my life I've ever tasted life!

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Life, gentlemen, is wonderful, but very dangerous. You must have courage for it, then it's wonderful. You gentlemen don't know that because you are all healthy and happy, but I -- believe me -- a man must know death and not until then does a man know anything about life.

turns.speaker: A MAN
turns.text: Rejoice in life while yet the small lamp burns.

turns.speaker: A MAN
turns.text: It's a short life and a gay one...

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Every glass high to life -- the splendid, dangerous, mighty, brief -- brief life -- and the courage to live it.  Baron, you know -- I've only lived since last night -- but that little while seems longer than all the time before -- all the --

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: No -- I told you not to come in this lobby.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I've told you a hundred times not to speak to me with a cigarette in your mouth.

turns.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
turns.text: You are late -- the dancer's gone to the theatre.

turns.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
turns.text: She's gone to the theatre -- don't you know?

turns.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
turns.text: And what are you going to do?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: The pearls are in her room.

turns.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
turns.text: Now listen to me. The others are getting suspicious of you. I was on the telephone to Amsterdam today, they think you're scared.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I've been careful, I've been waiting my chance.

turns.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
turns.text: You've been waiting your chance. You're too much of a gentleman -- that's the trouble with you.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I told you I'll get the pearls tonight.

turns.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
turns.text: Have you got that skeleton key?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: The floor clerk is out there in the corridor -- she sees everything ---

turns.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
turns.text: I could take care of her.

turns.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
turns.text: Chloroform on a handkerchief from behind -- while you...

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Poor girl -- chloroform would give her a rotten headache... I know -- I had it in the war. Besides, she's very pretty -- not young but --

turns.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
turns.text: You're no good for this business. It's just a joke to you...

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Get out and leave it to me... be ready to leave on the night train for Amsterdam...

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I'm not going to get those pearls and neither are you.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I have an idea working in my head...

turns.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
turns.text: You might find a bullet through that head...

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: If you did that, you'd get nothing except the police after you. If you wait -- I'll give you your six thousand back --

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Oh, my large and noisy neighbor -- really? That?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Oh... poor child. If you were free, I'd ask you to come and have some tea -- but --

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Tea would spoil my dinner.  One meal a day, I'd hate to spoil it.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Lord no -- charming -- but why one meal a day?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Yes -- yes indeed -- but you are a...  ...a stenographer. Don't little stenographers earn little pennies?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Did you ever see a stenographer with a decent frock on? -- One that she'd bought herself?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Poor child --  I wish I were free tonight -- we could --

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Unfortunately no -- to bad -- tomorrow though.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Shall we say five o'clock -- downstairs?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Will you do me a big favor?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Would you like to make a man happy?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Then dance the next number with Kringelein.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: You're not a bit like you were yesterday.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I fell in love last night -- the real thing.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Oh -- there's no real thing -- it doesn't exist.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I thought that, too -- but I found that it does. Come along, dance with Kringelein.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Flaemmchen, what are you doing here in the middle of the night.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Looking for my room -- one sixty- six.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: And Baron, thanks so much for everything.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Please do not be frightened, Madam.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Why do you hide in my room?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: But surely you must know -- because I love you.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Because you love me -- you love me?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Poor little Grusinskaya! Does it do you good to cry? Are you afraid? Shall I go?

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: I was so alone -- always alone -- and suddenly you were there and said that.  No. I am not afraid. It is strange.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Don't cry -- it tears my heart to see you sob like that.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Nerves -- just nerves. You must forgive me. I have had a bad evening. I am very tired. Do you know what it is to be tired -- tired of a routine existence?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I'm afraid not -- I usually do just what I feel like doing at the moment.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: So you feel like coming into a lady's room -- and you come... What now?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I'd like to smoke a cigarette.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Why do you look at me like that?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I did not know you were so beautiful... and --

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: No irony. You're so appealing -- so soft -- so tired. I feel like taking you in my arms and not letting anything more happen to you -- ever.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Alone. All alone.  Oh, you strange -- strange creature.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: You mustn't talk Russian to me.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Am I quite strange to you?

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Not quite strange now. It is as if I had been expecting you. You know, once when the Grand Duke was alive, I found a man hiding in my room -- a young officer --

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: He disappeared. Later he was found dead.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I never knew it was so dangerous to hide in a woman's room when she's alone.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: A man who could love -- that is all, who has forgotten everything else for you.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: You could love me. It is so long since I have heard that word. Nobody has loved me for a long time. It is so icy-cold to be famous. One is so cruelly alone. How is it that you -- Let me look at you. Your hands. Your eyes. Why could you love me?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I saw you just now -- then I saw you cry -- and now I see you in the mirror -- Grusinskaya...

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Grusinskaya... Oh -- oh if you knew how I slaved and slaved for Grusinskaya -- for the success of Grusinskaya -- for the triumph of Grusinskaya... and what is she now? Just someone who has found that on the day success ceases life ceases -- Are you listening to me -- Do you understand? -- I want you to understand.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: I think you must go now -- the key is on the floor.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I'm not going -- You know I'm not going -- Let me stay here?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: That is not so -- you don't want to be alone.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: No -- You don't want to be alone at all -- You were in despair before -- If I left you, you'd feel worse than you did before, You must not be alone -- You mustn't cry -- you must forget... Tell me that I can stay with you -- tell me.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: The stage frays one's nerves... the discipline -- it's so exacting. Discipline means doing what you don't want to do and take no pleasure in doing. Do you know what I mean? Have you ever experienced the weariness that comes from discipline?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I? -- Oh, no. I do only what I take pleasure in doing.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: I see -- you do only what you take pleasure in doing. You take pleasure in coming into a woman's bedroom and you come. You take pleasure in a dangerous climb onto a balcony, so you do it... And what is your pleasure now?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Because I can see something in the mirror that you cannot. My dear --

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Beautiful but so sad. I did not know it was so dangerous to look into a woman's bedroom.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I'm not going... You know that I'm not going... Do you think I could leave you alone here? After that --?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: The veronal -- you. I'm going to stay here with you.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: That is not the truth.  You do not want to be alone -- you're afraid of being alone -- I know you're afraid. I know you. You were desperate, just now, if I go away you'll be more desperate than ever. Say I am to stay with you... say it.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Oh -- I was ambitious then -- ambition was in my blood -- no rest, no stopping. We were drilled like little soldiers -- We danced in the school of the Imperial Ballet, in St. Petersburg. I was little and slim but hard as diamond -- a duty machine -- No rest, no stopping. And then -- I became famous and whoever is famous is alone... But why should I be telling you this? Last night I did not know you at all -- who are you, really? -- I do not even know your name.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I am Felix Benvenuto von Gaigern. My mother called me Flix.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Flix. -- And how do you live? What kind of a person are you?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I'm a prodigal son, the black sheep of a white flock -- I shall die on the gallows.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Really, I haven't a bit of character. None at all.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: When I was a little boy I was taught to ride and be a gentleman -- at school, it was a monastery, I learned to pray and lie -- and ---

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: And then, in the war, to kill and hide. That's all.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: And what do you do -- now?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I'm a gambler -- I'm running at large like a happy pig, devouring anything of life that pleases me, I really belong in jail

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Oh! What a picture -- and what else?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I'm also a criminal and a hotel thief.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Please look at me. You must believe me -- you must believe that I love you -- that I have never known what love is -- until last night.
